column1: A cabinet is a body of high-ranking state officials
column2: typically consisting of the top leaders of the executive branch. They are usually called ministers
column3: but in some jurisdictions are sometimes called secretaries.The functions of a cabinet are varied: in some countries it is a collegial decision-making body with collective responsibility
column4: while in others it may function either as a purely advisory body or an assisting institution to a decision making head of state or head of government. In some countries
column5: the cabinet is called "Council of Ministers" or "Government Council" or lesser known names such as "Federal Council" (in Switzerland)
column6: "Inner Council" or "High Council". These countries may differ in the way that the cabinet is used or established. In some countries
column7: particularly those that use a parliamentary system (e.g.
column9: the Cabinet collectively decides the government's direction
column10: especially in regard to legislation passed by the parliament. In countries with a presidential system
column12: the Cabinet does not function as a collective legislative influence; rather
column13: their primary role is as an official advisory council to the head of government.
